title: 109_hr5933
content: The "Business Travel Facilitation Act of 2006" may be cited as the Business Travel Facilitation Act. This Act pertains to business facilitation visitors. Section 214 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new category of visitors, business facilitation visitors, who are aliens visiting the US temporarily to provide services. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new category of visitors, business facilitation visitors, who can provide services under a qualifying contract or receive management training from a US entity. Conditions apply for admission as a business facilitation visitor. The Secretary of Homeland Security certifies countries combatting visa fraud with technology like biometrics. Consular officers assess visa applications based on evidence provided by the applicant. The alien must meet specific conditions for the provision of services, including having all remuneration and expenses paid by the employer and being qualified for the services. The alien must have expert knowledge and all necessary licenses to provide services in the United States. The alien must have expert knowledge and all necessary licenses to provide services in the United States. Conditions for management or technical training provision or receipt include being an employee of a firm affiliated with the US entity. The alien must have expert knowledge and necessary licenses to provide services in the United States. Conditions for training provision or receipt include being an employee of a firm affiliated with the US entity, entering into a joint venture, purchasing goods or services, or selling goods or services to the United States entity. The alien must have expert knowledge and necessary licenses to provide services in the United States. Conditions for training provision or receipt include being an employee of a firm affiliated with the US entity, entering into a joint venture, purchasing or selling goods or services to the United States entity. Remuneration and expenses related to training will be paid by the alien's employer. Management training requires at least 5 years of experience and detailed knowledge. The alien must have detailed knowledge of the business operations of their employer and hold a management level position within 1 year of completing training. The period of authorized admission for business facilitation visitors providing services is determined. The period of authorized admission for an alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor providing professional services shall not exceed 1 year, with a possible 6-month extension granted by the Secretary of Homeland Security in case of unforeseen delays in completing the services described in the contract. The period of authorized admission for an alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor providing or receiving management or technical training may not exceed 1 year. The period of authorized admission for an alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor, providing or receiving management or technical training, may not exceed 1 year. Additionally, such visitors are not eligible for a change of nonimmigrant status or adjustment to immigrant status during their stay in the United States. If the Secretary of Homeland Security identifies a pattern of fraud by nationals of a country in visa applications or immigration matters, those nationals may be prohibited from admission to the United States. The Secretary may prohibit nationals from admission to the United States as business facilitation visitors for a specified period if deemed necessary. A qualifying services contract involves a foreign provider of professional services fulfilling duties in the U.S. for a specified time period. The duties to be performed by the alien in the United States include provisions for remuneration, expenses paid by the foreign provider, and working conditions comparable to those of similarly situated providers of professional services. The alien must possess necessary credentials and comply with admission terms while providing services in the United States under the contract. The alien must possess necessary credentials and comply with admission terms while providing services in the United States under the contract, including admission to the United States and return to the alien's home country at the end of the admission period.
